content.question: A simple pendulum is set into simple harmonic motion. Which of the following graphs of the angular position <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> of the pendulum as a function of time indicates that the pendulum’s oscillation has a period of <math alttext="0.2 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math> and an amplitude of <math alttext="0.10 radians" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.10</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>rad</mi></math> ?

choices.label: The figure shows a curve in a coordinate plane with the origin labeled O. The horizontal axis is labeled “Time, in seconds,” and the numbers 0.1 to 0.5, in increments of 0.1, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Angular Position, in radians,” and the numbers negative 0.10 through 0.10, in increments of 0.05, are indicated. The curve is a sinusoidal wave that consists of three troughs of equal depth, at negative 0.05 theta in radians, and three peaks, at 0.05 theta in radians. The locations of the peaks and troughs are as follows. Peak 1: 0.0 seconds comma 0.05 theta in radians. Trough 1: 0.1 seconds comma negative 0.05 theta in radians. Peak 2: 0.2 seconds comma 0.05 theta in radians. Trough 2: 0.3 seconds comma negative 0.05 theta in radians. Peak 3: 0.4 seconds comma 0.05 theta in radians. Trough 3: 0.5 seconds comma negative 0.05 theta in radians.

The figure shows a curve in a coordinate plane with the origin labeled O. The horizontal axis is labeled “Time, in seconds,” and the numbers 0.1 to 0.5, in increments of 0.1, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Angular Position, in radians,” and the numbers negative 0.10 through 0.10, in increments of 0.05, are indicated. The curve is a sinusoidal wave that consists of three troughs of equal depth, at negative 0.10 theta in radians, and three peaks, at 0.10 theta in radians. The locations of the peaks and troughs are as follows. Peak 1: 0.0 seconds comma 0.10 theta in radians. Trough 1: 0.1 seconds comma negative 0.10 theta in radians. Peak 2: 0.2 seconds comma 0.10 theta in radians. Trough 2: 0.3 seconds comma negative 0.10 theta in radians. Peak 3: 0.4 seconds comma 0.10 theta in radians. Trough : 0.5 seconds comma negative 0.10 theta in radians.

The figure shows a curve in a coordinate plane with the origin labeled O. The horizontal axis is labeled “Time, in seconds,” and the numbers 0.1 to 0.5, in increments of 0.1, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Angular Position, in radians,” and the numbers negative 0.10 through 0.10, in increments of 0.05, are indicated. The curve is a sinusoidal wave that consists of one trough at negative 0.05 theta in radians, and two peaks at 0.05 theta in radians. The locations of the peaks and troughs are as follows. Peak 1: 0.1 seconds comma 0.05 theta in radians. Trough 1: 0.3 seconds comma negative 0.05 theta in radians. Peak 2: 0.5 seconds comma 0.05 theta in radians.

The vertical axis is labeled “Angular Position, in radians,” and the numbers negative 0.10 through 0.10, in increments of 0.05, are indicated. The curve is a sinusoidal wave that consists of one trough at negative 0.10 theta in radians, and two peaks at 0.10 theta in radians. The locations of the peaks and troughs are as follows. Peak 1: 0.1 seconds comma 0.10 theta in radians. Trough 1: 0.3 seconds comma negative 0.10 theta in radians. Peak 2: 0.5 seconds comma 0.10 theta in radians.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
